titleInfo.title: Cotton manufacturing
titleInfo.subTitle: United States Department of Agriculture ; Educational Film Service

mods.genre: Documentaries and factual films and video.

originInfo.publisher: United States Department of Agriculture

physicalDescription.extent: 1 reel of 4 (r1) (1007 ft.) : si., b&w ; 35 mm. ref print.
1 reel of 4 (r1) (1007 ft.) : si., b&w ; 35 mm. dupe neg.

mods.abstract: Large cotton mills along a riverfront are shown. In the year ending 7/31/16, more cotton than ever before was processed, totaling 7,278,529 bales, including linters. At the warehouse, cotton bales are weighed and then brought to the opening room, where the metal bands holding the bales together are removed. The cotton is loaded into a breaker-picker machine, which removes the heavier trash and prepares the cotton into an even weight lap. Depending on the grade of cotton, five to nine percent of the cotton is removed as waste. The beater machine cleans dirt from the cotton. The rolls of cotton lap are loaded onto the finisher picker for a finer cleaning. The laps are placed on the carding machine, which removes short fibers, motes and trash and forms the cotton into rope-like strands called sliver. Operators monitor and clean their machines. The amount of waste from the carding operation varies from five to nine percent according to the grade of cotton. The sliver and ribbon lap machines prepare the fibers in parallel condition for combing. The combers remove all short and matted fibers and the resulting cotton is used in the manufacture of high grade yarns.
mods.note: Title listed as Cotton manufacture in Motion pictures of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, 1920, p. 21 and in 1000 and one : the blue book of non-theatrical films, 1920, p. 26.
Unable to determine relationship of Educational Film Service to film; phone calls to National Archives and Records Administration and Dept. of Agriculture resulted in no information.

Originally, film was available for borrowing or purchase through Dept. of Agriculture field workers or state college extension services per Motion pictures of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, 1920, p. 5-6; distributor given as U.S. Dept. of Agriculture in 1000 and one : the blue book of non-theatrical films, 1920, p. 26; distributor was Federal Extension Service per phone call to Gary H. Stern, National Archives and Records Administration, Film and Video Branch, 1/5/96, but that body was established in 1923.
Year of production is 1919 per phone call to Gary H. Stern, National Archives and Records Administration, Film and Video Branch, 1/5/96; probably also released in 1919.

At the beginning of film: part I and at the end of film: end of part I, part II will follow immediately; film listed as 4 reels in 1000 and one : the blue book of non-theatrical films, 1920, p. 21 also lists film as 4 reels; four reels of this film were originally shown together.

On credits: property of the Board of Public Education, Division of Visual Education, School District of Philadelphia; this copy was probably purchased by and was owned by the School District of Philadelphia.

Sources used: phone call to Gary H. Stern, National Archives and Records Administration, Film and Video Branch, 1/5/96; Motion pictures of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, 1920, p. 5-6, 21; 1000 and one : the blue book of non-theatrical films, 1920, p. 26.
ref print and dupe neg; Received: 12/2/83 from LC film lab; preservation; AFI/Atkinson (Dennis) Collection.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Converted from MARCXML to MODS version 3.6 using MARC21slim2MODS3-6.xsl (Revision 1.119 2018/06/21)

name.namePart: Department of Health and Human Services.

originInfo.publisher: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and U.S. Department of Agriculture,

mods.abstract: Every 5 years since 1980, a new edition of the Dietary Guidelines for Americans has been published. Its goal is to make recommendations about the components of a healthy and nutritionally adequate diet to help promote health and prevent chronic disease for current and future generations. Although many of its recommendations have remained relatively consistent over time, the Dietary Guidelines has evolved as scientific knowledge has grown. These advancements have provided a greater understanding of, and focus on, the importance of healthy eating patterns as a whole, and how foods and beverages act synergistically to affect health. The Dietary Guidelines is designed for professionals to help all individuals ages 2 years and older and their families consume a healthy, nutritionally adequate diet. The information in the Dietary Guidelines is used in developing Federal food, nutrition, and health policies and programs. It also is the basis for Federal nutrition education materials designed for the public and for the nutrition education components of HHS and USDA food programs. It is developed for use by policymakers and nutrition and health professionals. Additional audiences who may use Dietary Guidelines information to develop programs, policies, and communication for the general public include businesses, schools, community groups, media, the food industry, and State and local governments. Previous editions of the Dietary Guidelines focused primarily on individual dietary components such as food groups and nutrients. However, people do not eat food groups and nutrients in isolation but rather in combination, and the totality of the diet forms an overall eating pattern. The components of the eating pattern can have interactive and potentially cumulative effects on health. These patterns can be tailored to an individual's personal preferences, enabling Americans to choose the diet that is right for them. A growing body of research has examined the relationship between overall eating patterns, health, and risk of chronic disease, and findings on these relationships are sufficiently well established to support dietary guidance. As a result, eating patterns and their food and nutrient characteristics are a focus of the recommendations in the 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines.
mods.note: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, U.S. Department of Agriculture.

"This new edition of the Dietary Guidelines, the 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans, is grounded in the most current scientific evidence and is informed by the recommendations of the 2015 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee"--Message from the Secretaries.
